componenttext: Got it. Excellent. Can you elaborate, any other further successes? I know we're just a few weeks out in terms of the Peruvian or anything like that and also in terms of Mexico on the marketing efforts, those both seem somewhat tangible [indiscernible].

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think to answer the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids wil
componenttext: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think to answer the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids will be going out for additional renewable resources to meet the standards that have been set by Mexico. And then what's significant about the Pima project is this is one of the very first projects to be assigned with an industrial customer. And we think that, that's a really interesting market to have some opportunities to directly sign up with some of the commercial industrial customers to provide them renewable resources. Also in Mexico, we're still expecting bids coming out on the electric transmission side. And as we told you at the conference, we think there's some great opportunities to continue our efforts in the liquids side of the business and don't have anything specific to announce in that area, but we see a lot of interest in finding a partner like IEnova to build the infrastructure on the liquids side of the business. And as you know, we already have an ethane pipeline and a terminal. And so we've been in that business and we think it has some great opportunities for us. On the Peruvian pipeline, I will ask Steve Davis to add any color to that. But what I will tell you is that it looks like that, that project will go out for bid, and that it's likely to go out for bid later this year or the beginning of next year. And our focus has been on ensuring that the bid terms will allow for a truly competitive bid process with participants that are concerned about not taking on any Foreign Corrupt Practice Act responsibilities. And as you know, we backed away from that when we felt that we could not get the kind of a clean deal that we felt that we could execute on. And so we have had some meetings with government officials, encouraging them to create a bit that ensures that the project is going to be financeable and that there will be adequate opportunities to bid in the way that the bid is structured. Steve, I don't know if you want to add anything more to that?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017

componenttext: Yes, the only thing I will add, as you know, we talked a little bit about this at the analyst conference and we obviously know a lot about the project. And as Debbie had mentioned, we are having discussions with the government. And to the extent that it fits our risk profile, we'll take another look at it. We expect something to happen either later this year or the first part of next year.

componenttext: I mean, this has been part of what we've told you all along that we want to remind you that, that -- because we start, I mean, it's a good thing. And so that contract has to stop so that we can begin the testing of the train for the export. And that impacts us financially later this year and the beginning of next year, all which have been incorporated into our base plan.

componenttext: If your question is, does that reduce the sensitivity, the gas prices, no because it's really not dependent upon gas prices. The gas price sensitivity is really tied to the plant and the contract at the ICA plant plus any gas in storage that has volatility during the course of the year.

componenttext: Michael, as I had mentioned at the analyst conference in that kind of looking at to be incremental capital opportunities, they were both highlighted. And we talked about quarter 2 filings, of which we made a filing on the 28th and then one just on Friday for the Master Meter project. So both are in alignment with what our plan is. The CapEx associated with the SDG&E Customer Information System is about $250 million. And at the gas company for the mobile home park, it's about a $270 million capital project. So both are solid projects that we look forward to timely approval of those going forward.

componenttext: Well, the good news is we've had 2 very successful pilot projects, both SDG&E and the gas company so the commission is very well aware of our track record. And so we think we will get a timely decision likely into 2018 and we would begin immediately after the approval.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Joe, I want to come back a little bit to the Cameron project. And I know you talked with Phil from CBI but also note that in the earnings call yesterday, one of Phil's colleagues, Patrick Mullen, used the comment when asked about Cameron LNG and
componenttext: Okay. And Joe, I want to come back a little bit to the Cameron project. And I know you talked with Phil from CBI but also note that in the earnings call yesterday, one of Phil's colleagues, Patrick Mullen, used the comment when asked about Cameron LNG and the startup, and I'll quote, "We expect the phase startup of these 3 trains starting in the latter half of next year." That may have just been kind of bundling of Train 1 and Train 2 with one supposed to be midyear and one supposed to be at the end of the year. Or you could interpret that as, "Hey, everything's moving a little bit more again." Would love your thoughts, if any.

componenttext: Okay. Yes, thanks, Michael. I obviously read that as well and I think you can read it a number of different ways. I think what he was saying wasn't different from what my discussion was with Phil was because I've been in a number of conversations with Pat, and I think they believe that they are in the schedule that they gave us. So I think he was just commenting altogether. He basically said all the trains are moving toward getting into operation in the second part of the year, which is very consistent with what we said.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: So a lot of my questions have been answered but just a few quick ones. So I was wondering how the Australian LNG curtailment potential might impact you guys. What kind of opportunities you guys might see or just in general, what it means for the market? T
componenttext: So a lot of my questions have been answered but just a few quick ones. So I was wondering how the Australian LNG curtailment potential might impact you guys. What kind of opportunities you guys might see or just in general, what it means for the market? That was my first question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's why
componenttext: Yes, I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's why we've moved forward, we're trying to get Port Arthur in the marketing stage where we are right now. And while we're trying to get the issues with Cameron Train 4 resolved so that we can get into the market for that. And I think what you're seeing is what we have been predicting all along as there was going to be a demand need in the market come that kind of time frame. And that's why we've continued to work on development of our projects. Joe if you want to talk about the Australian curtailment?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see th
componenttext: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see that over a long term. And I can see that the meetings that we've had together with Woodside, where we were jointly marketing the Port Arthur facility, went very well and there's quite a lot of interest in that facility. And I think that what's going on in Australia, it just shows that not necessarily getting these things done means that always that, that's going to be available or available for a longer period of time. So I'm not sure it's going to have an immediate effect but it starts to show that the end users are seriously starting to contemplate the need to go FID pretty soon, if not this year, next year or in the next year, so that they can make sure that they can meet the needs that they have and don't get in trouble if something like that were to become more serious. And so I think that having Woodside along with us has been very good for the project and for us. And so we look forward to trying to get these things signed up.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's been positive for the most part and -- but you don't actually see any sort of near-term potential opportunities that are going to be developed if I'm understanding what you guys are saying? Is that right?
componenttext: Okay. So it's been positive for the most part and -- but you don't actually see any sort of near-term potential opportunities that are going to be developed if I'm understanding what you guys are saying? Is that right?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would like to make sure I understand your question. You're talking about near-term development projects in Australia or here?
componenttext: I would like to make sure I understand your question. You're talking about near-term development projects in Australia or here?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, no, I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about, first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up t
componenttext: No, no, I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about, first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up the market perhaps in Asia? And then secondly, doesn't make, and it sounds like you were saying that it does, it doesn't make people more interesting in something like Port Arthur or other opportunities that you guys are exploring in terms of getting supply that may not be as -- I'm sorry, that might not have as much risk perhaps associated with something like we're seeing in Australia.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because the supply that drives that or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.S. m
componenttext: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because the supply that drives that or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.S. market, you don't have one dedicated supply source for the gas. And you also have the ability to sell off the gas at liquid points in the U.S. if you don't want to take the gas. I actually think that what's happening in Australia and in some of these other locations, where the supply store starts to get more constrained, makes it way better for the U.S. in terms of marketing our projects. And so that's the opportunity that we see right now and I think Woodside sees a similar view. They've been very excited about our Port Arthur project from the beginning. And I think being in Australia and company, they see the benefit of that as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then the second question I have is that we're seeing -- there was an announcement last -- yesterday on some immigration enforcement by the DOJ with respect to another LNG facility. And we've also been hearing in other industries potential
componenttext: Okay, great. And then the second question I have is that we're seeing -- there was an announcement last -- yesterday on some immigration enforcement by the DOJ with respect to another LNG facility. And we've also been hearing in other industries potential issues with immigration raising construction prices, delaying in-service dates and stuff. And I was just wondering or at least the risk that's being perceived to that, I was just wondering if that, is it all an issue that you guys are thinking about in terms of just the cost and scheduling with LNG.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Ch
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman, President and CEO; Jeff Martin, Chief Financial Officer; Steve Davis, corporate Group President of Utilities; Joe Householder, Corporate Group President of Infrastructure; Dennis Arriola, Executive Vice President; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; and Trevor Mihalek, Chief Accounting Officer.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. 
It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts are shown on a diluted basis, and we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our first quarter 2017 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures.
I'd also like to mention that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, May 9, 2017, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future.
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the web
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. 
Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the webcast for our analyst conference a few weeks ago. I appreciate the useful feedback we received. For those of you who are unable to attend, you can find all of the conference materials on our website. 
I'd like to start off by reiterating Sempra's long-term value drivers. First, we expect to grow our EPS 10% to 11% from 2017 through 2021 by successfully executing on projects already under contract and our infrastructure businesses and our expected utility performance. 
Second, we plan to grow our dividend from 2017 by 8% to 9% annually, then reassess it for additional increases after Cameron's 3 trains come online. And third, our increased cash flow should provide $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion in additional debt capacity in 2021. This offers us the flexibility to further enhance long-term shareholder value. And fourth, we expect to capture opportunities over the next 5 years to add to or extend our earnings growth. 
Before I turn it over to Jeff, please turn to Slide 5. One of the ways we measure our success is delivering on our EPS guidance. Jeff will review a few of our recent operational successes and our first quarter results, which keep us on track to meet our 2017 earnings guidance of $4.85 to $5.25 per share. Jeff?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be approved. 
Second, we're focused on executing the capital plan that we laid out at our conference by advancing major projects, in particular, Cameron Trains 1 through 3 and the Marine Pipeline. We've also made near-term progress on several other projects. At SDG&E, we signed 5 new contracts for battery storage facilities totaling 83.5 megawatts, 70 of which will be directly owned by SDG&E. 
SDG&E also placed one of the largest lithium ion battery systems in the world into service in the first quarter. Many of you had the opportunity to visit SDG&E during the conference to hear about this and how it supports California's electrification efforts as well as furthering the state's policy goal by reducing carbon emissions.
IEnova expects to complete 3 natural gas pipelines by the end of the second quarter. This also represents the combined investment of close to $900 million. Each project, you'll recall, is backed by 25-year U.S. dollar-denominated contract with CSC. 
Third, we're also looking at new investment opportunities. Let me list a few examples: IEnova recently agreed to construct a solar facility with a 20-year PPA for 110 megawatts with an industrial steel company. This is the first bilateral agreement in Mexico under the new market for renewables where the off-taker is a private company. We anticipate there'll be more opportunities like this. 
The Pima solar facility is expected to cost roughly $115 million and be operational by the end of 2018. This project is also a great example of how we, at Sempra, leverage our experience across different growth platforms. The success we've demonstrated in U.S. renewable business allows us to compete more effectively for projects just like this in Mexico.
We also made CPUC filings for additional projects, representing the potential for almost $500 million of new capital. To be clear, these projects were not included in the capital plan we outlined at the analyst conference. These projects include: an expansion of SoCalGas's Master Meter program for mobile home parks and SDG&E's proposal to replace its customer information system.
Now please turn to the next slide. Our first quarter financial results was the strongest first quarter performance Sempra has experienced since it was formed. Earlier this morning, we reported first quarter earnings of $441 million or $1.75 per share. This compares favorably to first quarter 2016 earnings of $353 million or $1.40 per share. 
On an adjusted basis, we recorded earnings of $438 million or $1.74 per share. Again, this compares to fourth quarter 2016 adjusted earnings of $404 million or $1.60 per share. You'll also recall that we adopted a new accounting standard on stock-based compensation in the third quarter of last year. This was applied retroactively to the first quarter of 2016 and accordingly increased earnings by $34 million in that period.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 to discuss the key factors impacting our results. Our higher quarter-over-quarter adjusted earnings were driven by strong operating results, including $18 million of higher operating earnings from SDG&E and South America, $21 million of higher earnings at our California Utilities. This is largely as a result of the delay of the 2016 GRC file decision. These earnings were recorded in the second quarter of 2016, plus $29 million of higher earnings at Sempra Mexico related to the GdC and Ventika acquisitions and higher AFUDC earnings. 
Also an improvement in earnings this year were $14 million of higher tax benefit and lower interest cost at parent. These items were partially offset by $34 million of tax benefit from 2016 compared to $3 million of tax expense in 2017 associated with share-based compensation, and at Sempra Mexico, $25 million of lower earnings from foreign currency and inflation effects primarily from current quarter losses.
If you will, I'd like to spend a moment on foreign currency. You'll recall that our current hedging strategy limits our FX-related exposure on U.S. dollar debt in Mexico. While we expect some intra-quarter volatility from time to time, our hedging strategy over the full year is designed to reduce or eliminate expenses related to this exposure. 
You'll also recall that there are other FX exposures that impact earnings but not cash flow. These occur in Mexico and South America, and we do not hedge these additional costs. These exposures have historically largely offset over a full year when the currencies move in a similar way. You'll find additional details on the FX in the appendix. 
And with that, we'll conclude with our prepared comments and stop to take any additional questions that you might have.

componenttext: I'm going to have Steve Davis talk a little bit about that. But just to remind everyone, this was an all-party settlement. componenttext: There's been no real indication but what I will say from my 30, almost 40 years of experience, is that when you have new commissioners coming in for a major decision for the first time on that, oftentimes, they want to take a little bit more time and fully understand the issues. And that is usually the assigned commissioner would allow for that to happen. So we're not reading anything more into it that there's like any major concern. And were not getting indications of major concerns in the meetings that we had so far.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think the answer to the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids
componenttext: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think the answer to the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids will be going out for additional renewable resources to meet the standards that have been set by Mexico. And then what's significant about the Pima project is this is one of the very first projects to be assigned with an industrial customer. And we think that, that's a really interesting market to have some opportunities to directly sign up with some of the commercial industrial customers to provide them renewable resources. Also in Mexico, we're still expecting bids coming out on the electric transmission side. And as we told you at the conference, we think there's some great opportunities to continue our efforts in the liquids side of the business. And don't have anything specific to announce in that area, but we see a lot of interest in finding a partner like IEnova to build the infrastructure on the liquids side of the business. And as you know, we already have an ethane pipeline and a terminal. And so we've been in that business and we think it has some great opportunities for us. On the Peruvian pipeline, I will ask Steve Davis to add any color to that. But what I will tell you is that it looks like that, that project will go out for bid, and that it's likely to go out for bid later this year or the beginning of next year. And our focus has been on ensuring that the bid terms will allow for a truly competitive bid process with participants that are concerned about not taking on any Foreign Corrupt Practice Act responsibilities. And as you know, we backed away from that when we felt that we could not get the kind of a clean deal that we felt that we could execute on. And so we have had some meetings with the government officials, encouraging them to create a bit that ensures that the project is going to be financeable and that there will be adequate opportunities to bid in the way that the bid is structured. Steve, I don't know if you want to add anything more to that.

componenttext: Yes, the only thing I will add, Julien, as you know, we talked a little bit about this at the analyst conference, and we obviously know a lot about the project. And we expect something to happen either later this year or the first part of next year.

componenttext: Debbie. Michael, as I had mentioned at the analyst conference in that kind of looking at some of the incremental capital opportunities, they were both highlighted. And we talked about quarter 2 filings, of which we made a filing on the 28th and then one just on Friday for the Master Meter project. So both are in alignment with what our plan is. The CapEx associated with the SDG&E Customer Information System is about $250 million. And at the gas company for the mobile home park, it's about a $270 million capital project. So both are solid projects that we look forward to timely approval of those going forward.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's why we've moved forward. We're trying to get Port Arthur in the marketing stage where we are right now. And while we're trying to get the issues with Cameron Train 4 resolved so that we can get into the market for that. And I think what you're seeing is what we have been predicting all along as there was going to be a demand need in the market come that kind of time frame. And that's why we've continued to work on development of our projects. Joe, do you want to talk about the Australian curtailment?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see
componenttext: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see that over a long term. And I can say that the meetings that we've had together with Woodside, where we were jointly marketing the Port Arthur facility, went very well, and there's quite a lot of interest in that facility. And I think that what's going on in Australia, it just shows that not necessarily getting these things done means that always that, that's going to be available or available for a longer period of time. So I'm not sure it's going to have an immediate effect but it starts to show that the end users are seriously starting to contemplate the need to go FID pretty soon, if not this year, next year or in the next year, so that they can make sure that they meet the needs that they have and don't get in trouble if something like that were to become more serious. And so I think that having Woodside along with us has been very good for the project and for us. And so we look forward to trying to get these things signed up.

componenttext: No, no. I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about -- first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up the market perhaps in Asia? And then secondly, does it make, and it sounds like you were saying that it does, does it make people more interested in something like Port Arthur or other opportunities that you guys are exploring in terms of getting supply that may not be as -- I'm sorry, that may not have as much risk perhaps associated with it like something we're seeing in Australia.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.
componenttext: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.S. market, you don't have one dedicated supply source for the gas. And you also have the ability to sell off the gas at liquid points in the U.S. if you don't want to take the gas. I actually think that what's happening in Australia and in some of these other locations, where the supply store starts to get more constrained, makes it way better for the U.S. in terms of marketing our projects. And so that's the opportunity that we see right now. And I think Woodside sees a similar view. They've been very excited about our Port Arthur project from the beginning. And I think being in Australia and company, they see the benefit of that as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Ch
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman, President and CEO; Jeff Martin, Chief Financial Officer; Steve Davis, corporate Group President of Utilities; Joe Householder, Corporate Group President of Infrastructure; Dennis Arriola, Executive Vice President; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; and Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. 
It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts are shown on a diluted basis, and we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our first quarter 2017 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures.
I'd also like to mention that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, May 9, 2017, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future.
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the web
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. 
Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the webcast for our analyst conference a few weeks ago. I appreciate the useful feedback we received. For those of you who are unable to attend, you can find all of the conference materials on our website. 
I'd like to start off by reiterating Sempra's long-term value drivers. First, we expect to grow our EPS 10% to 11% from 2017 through 2021 by successfully executing on projects already under contract and our infrastructure businesses and our expected utility performance. 
Second, we plan to grow our dividend from 2017 by 8% to 9% annually, then reassess it for additional increases after Cameron's 3 trains come online. And third, our increased cash flow should provide $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion in additional debt capacity in 2021. This offers us the flexibility to further enhance long-term shareholder value. And fourth, we expect to capture opportunities over the next 5 years to add to or extend our earnings growth. 
Before I turn it over to Jeff, please turn to Slide 5. One of the ways we measure our success is delivering on our EPS guidance. Jeff will review a few of our recent operational successes and our first quarter results, which keep us on track to meet our 2017 earnings guidance of $4.85 to $5.25 per share. Jeff?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be approved. 
Second, we're focused on executing the capital plan that we laid out at our conference by advancing major projects, in particular, Cameron Trains 1 through 3 and the Marine Pipeline. We've also made near-term progress on several other projects. At SDG&E, we signed 5 new contracts for battery storage facilities totaling 83.5 megawatts, 70 of which will be directly owned by SDG&E. 
SDG&E also placed one of the largest lithium ion battery systems in the world into service in the first quarter. Many of you had the opportunity to visit SDG&E during the conference to hear about this and how it supports California's electrification efforts as well as furthering the state's policy goal by reducing carbon emissions.
IEnova expects to complete 3 natural gas pipelines by the end of the second quarter. This also represents the combined investment of close to $900 million. Each project, you'll recall, is backed by 25-year U.S. dollar-denominated contract with [ CSC ]. 
Third, we're also looking at new investment opportunities. Let me list a few examples: IEnova recently agreed to construct a solar facility with a 20-year PPA for 110 megawatts with an industrial steel company. This is the first bilateral agreement in Mexico under the new market for renewables where the off-taker is a private company. We anticipate there'll be more opportunities like this. 
The Pima solar facility is expected to cost roughly $115 million and be operational by the end of 2018. This project is also a great example of how we, at Sempra, leverage our experience across different growth platforms. The success we've demonstrated in U.S. renewable business allows us to compete more effectively for projects just like this in Mexico.
We also made CPUC filings for additional projects, representing the potential for almost $500 million of new capital. To be clear, these projects were not included in the capital plan we outlined at the analyst conference. These projects include: an expansion of SoCalGas's Master Meter program for mobile home parks and SDG&E's proposal to replace its customer information system.
Now please turn to the next slide. Our first quarter financial results was the strongest first quarter performance Sempra has experienced since it was formed. Earlier this morning, we reported first quarter earnings of $441 million or $1.75 per share. This compares favorably to first quarter 2016 earnings of $353 million or $1.40 per share. 
On an adjusted basis, we recorded earnings of $438 million or $1.74 per share. Again, this compares to fourth quarter 2016 adjusted earnings of $404 million or $1.60 per share. You'll also recall that we adopted a new accounting standard on stock-based compensation in the third quarter of last year. This was applied retroactively to the first quarter of 2016 and accordingly increased earnings by $34 million in that period.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 to discuss the key factors impacting our results. Our higher quarter-over-quarter adjusted earnings were driven by strong operating results, including $18 million of higher operating earnings from SDG&E and South America, $21 million of higher earnings at our California Utilities. This is largely as a result of the delay of the 2016 GRC [ file ] decision. These earnings were recorded in the second quarter of 2016, plus $29 million of higher earnings at Sempra Mexico related to the GdC and Ventika acquisitions and higher AFUDC earnings. 
Also an improvement in earnings this year were $14 million of higher tax benefit and lower interest cost at parent. These items were partially offset by $34 million of tax benefit from 2016 compared to $3 million of tax expense in 2017 associated with share-based compensation, and at Sempra Mexico, $25 million of lower earnings from foreign currency and inflation effects primarily from current quarter losses.
If you will, I'd like to spend a moment on foreign currency. You'll recall that our current hedging strategy limits our FX-related exposure on U.S. dollar debt in Mexico. While we expect some intra-quarter volatility from time to time, our hedging strategy over the full year is designed to reduce or eliminate expenses related to this exposure. 
You'll also recall that there are other FX exposures that impact earnings but not cash flow. These occur in Mexico and South America, and we do not hedge these additional costs. These exposures have historically largely offset over a full year when the currencies move in a similar way. You'll find additional details on the FX in the appendix. 
And with that, we'll conclude with our prepared comments and stop to take any additional questions that you might have.

componenttext: There's been no real indication but what I will say from my 30, almost 40 years of experience, is that when you have new commissioners coming in for a major decision for the first time on that, oftentimes, they want to take a little bit more time and fully understand the issues. And that is usually the assigned commissioner would allow for that to happen. So we're not reading anything more into it that there's like any major concern. And were not getting indications of major concerns in the meetings that we had so far.

But I'll have Jeff take you through that, and in particular, to have you understand kind of what we think is going to happen for the remainder of the year. So Jeff?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, Julien. On the $26 million improvement, roughly $15 million of that is from mark-to-market losses in the quarter last year. And as Debbie indicated, obviously, the natural gas prices have improved just over $1. I would also mention that at
componenttext: Good afternoon, Julien. On the $26 million improvement, roughly $15 million of that is from mark-to-market losses in the quarter last year. And as Debbie indicated, obviously, the natural gas prices have improved just over $1. I would also mention that at the end of this year, you'll think about the ENI contract we'll be rolling off. And I think if I were to guide you in terms of how we think about the year, this segment we showed you at the analyst conference would report roughly $40 million to $50 million of negative results for the year. And we still think that's the best way to think about it.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017

componenttext: Got it. Excellent. Can you elaborate, any other further successes? I know we're just a few weeks out in terms of the Peruvian bid or anything like that and also in terms of Mexico on the marketing efforts. Those both seem somewhat tangible [indiscernible].

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think the answer to the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids
componenttext: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think the answer to the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids will be going out for additional renewable resources to meet the standards that have been set by Mexico. And then what's significant about the Pima project is this is one of the very first projects to be assigned with an industrial customer. And we think that, that's a really interesting market to have some opportunities to directly sign up with some of the commercial industrial customers to provide them renewable resources. Also in Mexico, we're still expecting bids coming out on the electric transmission side. And as we told you at the conference, we think there's some great opportunities to continue our efforts in the liquids side of the business. And don't have anything specific to announce in that area, but we see a lot of interest in finding a partner like IEnova to build the infrastructure on the liquids side of the business. And as you know, we already have an ethane pipeline and a terminal. And so we've been in that business and we think it has some great opportunities for us. On the Peruvian pipeline, I will ask Steve Davis to add any color to that. But what I will tell you is that it looks like that, that project will go out for bid, and that it's likely to go out for bid later this year or the beginning of next year. And our focus has been on ensuring that the bid terms will allow for a truly competitive bid process with participants that are concerned about not taking on any Foreign Corrupt Practice Act responsibilities. And as you know, we backed away from that when we felt that we could not get the kind of a clean deal that we felt that we could execute on. And so we have had some meetings with the government officials, encouraging them to create a bit that ensures that the project is going to be financeable and that there will be adequate opportunities to bid in the way that the bid is structured. Steve, I don't know if you want to add anything more to that.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017

componenttext: Yes, the only thing I will add, Julien, as you know, we talked a little bit about this at the analyst conference, and we obviously know a lot about the project. And we -- as Debbie had mentioned, we are having discussions with the government. And to the extent that it fits our risk profile, we'll take another look at it. And we expect something to happen either later this year or the first part of next year.

And that impacts us financially later this year and the beginning of next year, all which have been incorporated into our base plans.

componenttext: Debbie. Michael, as I had mentioned at the analyst conference in that kind of looking at some of the incremental capital opportunities, they were both highlighted. And we talked about quarter 2 filings, of which we made a filing on the 28th and then one just on Friday for the Master Meter project. So both are in alignment with what our plan is. So both are solid projects that we look forward to timely approval of those going forward.

componenttext: Well, the good news is we've had 2 very successful pilot projects, both SDG&E and the gas company. So the commission is very well aware of our track record. And so we think we will get a timely decision likely into 2018, and we would begin immediately after the approval.

componenttext: So a lot of my questions have been answered but just a few quick ones. So I was wondering how the Australian LNG curtailment potential might impact you guys. What kind of opportunities you guys might see, or just in general, what it means for the market? That was my first question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's why we've moved forward. We're trying to get Port Arthur in the marketing stage where we are right now. And while we're trying to get the issues with Cameron Train 4 resolved so that we can get into the market for that. And I think what you're seeing is what we have been predicting all along as there was going to be a demand need in the market come that kind of time frame. And that's why we've continued to work on development of our projects. Joe, do you want to talk about the Australian curtailment?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see
componenttext: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see that over a long term. And I can say that the meetings that we've had together with Woodside, where we were jointly marketing the Port Arthur facility, went very well, and there's quite a lot of interest in that facility. And I think that what's going on in Australia, it just shows that not necessarily getting these things done means that always that, that's going to be available or available for a longer period of time. So I'm not sure it's going to have an immediate effect but it starts to show that the end users are seriously starting to contemplate the need to go FID pretty soon, if not this year, next year or in the next year, so that they can make sure that they meet the needs that they have and don't get in trouble if something like that were to become more serious. And so I think that having Woodside along with us has been very good for the project and for us. And so we look forward to trying to get these things signed up.

componenttext: No, no. I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about -- first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up the market perhaps in Asia? And then secondly, does it make, and it sounds like you were saying that it does, does it make people more interested in something like Port Arthur or other opportunities that you guys are exploring in terms of getting supply that may not be as -- I'm sorry, that may not have as much risk perhaps associated with it like something we're seeing in Australia.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.
componenttext: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.S. market, you don't have one dedicated supply source for the gas. And you also have the ability to sell off the gas at liquid points in the U.S. if you don't want to take the gas. I actually think that what's happening in Australia and in some of these other locations, where the supply store starts to get more constrained, makes it way better for the U.S. in terms of marketing our projects. And so that's the opportunity that we see right now. And I think Woodside sees a similar view. They've been very excited about our Port Arthur project from the beginning. And I think being an Australian company, they see the benefit of that as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Sempra Energy First Quarter Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. Rick Vaccari. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Ch
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Sempra Energy's First Quarter 2017 Financial Presentation. A live webcast of this teleconference and slide presentation is available on our website. Here in San Diego are several members of our management team: Debbie Reed, Chairman, President and CEO; Jeff Martin, Chief Financial Officer; Steve Davis, corporate Group President of Utilities; Joe Householder, Corporate Group President of Infrastructure; Dennis Arriola, Executive Vice President; Martha Wyrsch, General Counsel; and Trevor Mihalik, Chief Accounting Officer.
Before starting, I would like to remind everyone that we will be discussing forward-looking statements on this call within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those discussed today. The factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially are discussed in the company's most recent 10-K and 10-Q. 
It's important to note that all of the earnings per share amounts are shown on a diluted basis, and we will be discussing certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to the presentation slides that accompany this call and to Table A in our first quarter 2017 earnings press release for a reconciliation to GAAP measures.
I'd also like to mention that the forward-looking statements contained in this presentation speak only as of today, May 9, 2017, and the company does not assume any obligation to update or revise any of these forward-looking statements in the future.
With that, please turn to Slide 4, and let me hand the call over to Debbie.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the web
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us this morning. I first want to start by saying that I am going to be talking about Sempra, not whoever that other company was that the operator put on. 
Thanks, Rick, and thanks to all of you who joined us in San Diego or via the webcast for our analyst conference a few weeks ago. I appreciate the useful feedback we received. For those of you who are unable to attend, you can find all of the conference materials on our website. 
I'd like to start off by reiterating Sempra's long-term value drivers. First, we expect to grow our EPS 10% to 11% from 2017 through 2021 by successfully executing on projects already under contract and our infrastructure businesses and our expected utility performance. 
Second, we plan to grow our dividend from 2017 by 8% to 9% annually, then reassess it for additional increases after Cameron's 3 trains come online. And third, our increased cash flow should provide $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion in additional debt capacity in 2021. This offers us the flexibility to further enhance long-term shareholder value. And fourth, we expect to capture opportunities over the next 5 years to add to or extend our earnings growth. 
Before I turn it over to Jeff, please turn to Slide 5. One of the ways we measure our success is delivering on our EPS guidance. Jeff will review a few of our recent operational successes and our first quarter results, which keep us on track to meet our 2017 earnings guidance of $4.85 to $5.25 per share. Jeff?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Debbie. First, regarding the cost of capital, we remain constructive on this settlement and believe it's in the best interest of all parties, and we continue to expect that the settlement or something is substantially similar to what will be approved. 
Second, we're focused on executing the capital plan that we laid out at our conference by advancing major projects, in particular, Cameron Trains 1 through 3 and the Marine Pipeline. We've also made near-term progress on several other projects. At SDG&E, we signed 5 new contracts for battery storage facilities totaling 83.5 megawatts, 70 of which will be directly owned by SDG&E. 
SDG&E also placed one of the largest lithium ion battery systems in the world into service in the first quarter. Many of you had the opportunity to visit SDG&E during the conference to hear about this and how it supports California's electrification efforts as well as furthering the state's policy goal by reducing carbon emissions.
IEnova expects to complete 3 natural gas pipelines by the end of the second quarter. This also represents the combined investment of close to $900 million. Each project, you'll recall, is backed by 25-year U.S. dollar-denominated contract with [ CSC ]. 
Third, we're also looking at new investment opportunities. Let me list a few examples: IEnova recently agreed to construct a solar facility with a 20-year PPA for 110 megawatts with an industrial steel company. This is the first bilateral agreement in Mexico under the new market for renewables where the off-taker is a private company. We anticipate there'll be more opportunities like this. 
The Pima solar facility is expected to cost roughly $115 million and be operational by the end of 2018. This project is also a great example of how we, at Sempra, leverage our experience across different growth platforms. The success we've demonstrated in U.S. renewable business allows us to compete more effectively for projects just like this in Mexico.
We also made CPUC filings for additional projects, representing the potential for almost $500 million of new capital. To be clear, these projects were not included in the capital plan we outlined at the analyst conference. These projects include: an expansion of SoCalGas's Master Meter program for mobile home parks and SDG&E's proposal to replace its customer information system.
Now please turn to the next slide. Our first quarter financial results was the strongest first quarter performance Sempra has experienced since it was formed. Earlier this morning, we reported first quarter earnings of $441 million or $1.75 per share. This compares favorably to first quarter 2016 earnings of $353 million or $1.40 per share. 
On an adjusted basis, we recorded earnings of $438 million or $1.74 per share. Again, this compares to fourth quarter 2016 adjusted earnings of $404 million or $1.60 per share. You'll also recall that we adopted a new accounting standard on stock-based compensation in the third quarter of last year. This was applied retroactively to the first quarter of 2016 and accordingly increased earnings by $34 million in that period.
Now let's turn to Slide 7 to discuss the key factors impacting our results. Our higher quarter-over-quarter adjusted earnings were driven by strong operating results, including $18 million of higher operating earnings from SDG&E and South America, $21 million of higher earnings at our California Utilities. This is largely as a result of the delay of the 2016 GRC [ file ] decision. These earnings were recorded in the second quarter of 2016, plus $29 million of higher earnings at Sempra Mexico related to the GdC and Ventika acquisitions and higher AFUDC earnings. 
Also an improvement in earnings this year were $14 million of higher tax benefit and lower interest cost at parent. These items were partially offset by $34 million of tax benefit from 2016 compared to $3 million of tax expense in 2017 associated with share-based compensation, and at Sempra Mexico, $25 million of lower earnings from foreign currency and inflation effects primarily from current quarter losses.
If you will, I'd like to spend a moment on foreign currency. You'll recall that our current hedging strategy limits our FX-related exposure on U.S. dollar debt in Mexico. While we expect some intra-quarter volatility from time to time, our hedging strategy over the full year is designed to reduce or eliminate expenses related to this exposure. 
You'll also recall that there are other FX exposures that impact earnings but not cash flow. These occur in Mexico and South America, and we do not hedge these additional costs. These exposures have historically largely offset over a full year when the currencies move in a similar way. You'll find additional details on the FX in the appendix. 
And with that, we'll conclude with our prepared comments and stop to take any additional questions that you might have.

componenttext: There's been no real indication but what I will say from my 30, almost 40 years of experience, is that when you have new commissioners coming in for a major decision for the first time on that, oftentimes, they want to take a little bit more time and fully understand the issues. And that is usually the assigned commissioner would allow for that to happen. So we're not reading anything more into it that there's like any major concern. And were not getting indications of major concerns in the meetings that we had so far.

componenttext: Yes. As you say, it's only been 30 days out, Julien. But in that 30 days, we did announce a new solar project in Mexico. And we think the answer to the Mexico question first, there's some wonderful opportunities in terms of renewables there. A lot of bids will be going out for additional renewable resources to meet the standards that have been set by Mexico. And then what's significant about the Pima project is this is one of the very first projects to be assigned with an industrial customer. And we think that, that's a really interesting market to have some opportunities to directly sign up with some of the commercial industrial customers to provide them renewable resources. Also in Mexico, we're still expecting bids coming out on the electric transmission side. And as we told you at the conference, we think there's some great opportunities to continue our efforts in the liquids side of the business. And don't have anything specific to announce in that area, but we see a lot of interest in finding a partner like IEnova to build the infrastructure on the liquids side of the business. And as you know, we already have an ethane pipeline and a terminal. And so we've been in that business and we think it has some great opportunities for us. On the Peruvian pipeline, I will ask Steve Davis to add any color to that. But what I will tell you is that it looks like that, that project will go out for bid, and that it's likely to go out for bid later this year or the beginning of next year. And our focus has been on ensuring that the bid terms will allow for a truly competitive bid process with participants that are concerned about not taking on any Foreign Corrupt Practice Act responsibilities. And as you know, we backed away from that when we felt that we could not get the kind of a clean deal that we felt that we could execute on. And so we have had some meetings with the government officials, encouraging them to create a bit that ensures that the project is going to be financeable and that there will be adequate opportunities to bid in the way that the bid is structured. Steve, I don't know if you want to add anything more to that.

componenttext: Debbie. Michael, as I had mentioned at the analyst conference in that kind of looking at some of the incremental capital opportunities, they were both highlighted. componenttext: Well, the good news is we've had 2 very successful pilot projects, both SDG&E and the gas company. So the commission is very well aware of our track record. And so we think we will get a timely decision likely into 2018, and we would begin immediately after the approval.

componenttext: Okay. Yes. Thanks, Michael. I obviously read that as well, and I think you can read it a number of different ways. componenttext: So a lot of my questions have been answered but just a few quick ones. So I was wondering how the Australian LNG curtailment potential might impact you guys. What kind of opportunities you guys might see, or just in general, what it means for the market? That was my first question.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's
componenttext: Yes. I'm going to have Joe go into more details, but what I will say is that we've been saying all along that we saw a market opportunity in the 2021 to 2023 period. And I think now, the kind of the herd mentality is where we've been all along. And that's why we've moved forward. We're trying to get Port Arthur in the marketing stage where we are right now. And while we're trying to get the issues with Cameron Train 4 resolved so that we can get into the market for that. And I think what you're seeing is what we have been predicting all along as there was going to be a demand need in the market come that kind of time frame. And that's why we've continued to work on development of our projects. Joe, do you want to talk about the Australian curtailment?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see
componenttext: Sure. Hi, Paul. I guess what -- I would say it this way. I think that the long-term users of LNG, both in Asia and Europe, are looking for long-term solutions and reliability. And so they want to make sure that they're going to a source where they can see that over a long term. And I can say that the meetings that we've had together with Woodside, where we were jointly marketing the Port Arthur facility, went very well, and there's quite a lot of interest in that facility. And I think that what's going on in Australia, it just shows that not necessarily getting these things done means that always that, that's going to be available or available for a longer period of time. So I'm not sure it's going to have an immediate effect but it starts to show that the end users are seriously starting to contemplate the need to go FID pretty soon, if not this year, next year or in the next year, so that they can make sure that they meet the needs that they have and don't get in trouble if something like that were to become more serious. And so I think that having Woodside along with us has been very good for the project and for us. And so we look forward to trying to get these things signed up.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it's been positive for the most part and -- but you don't actually see any sort of near-term potential opportunities that are going to be developed if I'm understanding what you guys are saying? Is that right?
componenttext: Okay. So it's been positive for the most part and -- but you don't actually see any sort of near-term potential opportunities that are going to be developed if I'm understanding what you guys are saying? Is that right?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would like to make sure I understand your question. You're talking about near-term development projects in Australia or here?
componenttext: I would like to make sure I understand your question. You're talking about near-term development projects in Australia or here?

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: No, no. I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about -- first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up
componenttext: No, no. I mean with you guys. I mean, if you're having curtailments, that would suggest that people might have concerns about -- first of all, what does it mean for just LNG sales in the near term in the market? What does it mean in terms of tightening up the market perhaps in Asia? And then secondly, does it make, and it sounds like you were saying that it does, does it make people more interested in something like Port Arthur or other opportunities that you guys are exploring in terms of getting supply that may not be as -- I'm sorry, that may not have as much risk perhaps associated with it like something we're seeing in Australia.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.
componenttext: I mean, we have talked to you all about what we saw with the advantages of the U.S. project over these projects with dedicated supply sources because there's a  supply that dries up or that there's a problem of getting that supply to market. And in the U.S. market, you don't have one dedicated supply source for the gas. And you also have the ability to sell off the gas at liquid points in the U.S. if you don't want to take the gas. I actually think that what's happening in Australia and in some of these other locations, where the supply store starts to get more constrained, makes it way better for the U.S. in terms of marketing our projects. And so that's the opportunity that we see right now. And I think Woodside sees a similar view. They've been very excited about our Port Arthur project from the beginning. And I think being an Australian company, they see the benefit of that as well.

headline: Sempra Energy, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, May 09, 2017

And I was just wondering -- or at least the risk that's being perceived to that. I was just wondering if that -- is it all an issue that you guys are thinking about in terms of just the cost and scheduling with the LNG?

componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Debbie. So I think as you just said, we saw this article this morning and didn't -- yes, we haven't heard that so that didn't sound like it was us. I checked. It wasn't us. It wasn't CC JV and it wasn't their contractors. We have controls in place around that. Also, you heard that on the call yesterday, Phil mentioned that they were employing a great number of people, and they have a huge roster of people that they're going to bring people on-site, and they haven't really had problems bringing people onto the site. So I think their controls are very sound, and we haven't seen this problem. Obviously, one of the reasons that we hired this consortium of contractors to work on this project was they have a large resource of people to go to bring to the site, and very much so in Louisiana.
